text: EXTREME CLOSEUPS OF FLICKERING INSTRUMENT PANELS.  Readou displays pulse eerily with the technology of the distant Wherever we are, it seems to be chill, dark, and sterile. machinery chuckles softly to itself. Abruptly we hear a BEEPING SIGNAL, and the machinery begi Circuits close, lights blink on. CAMERA ANGLES GRADUALLY WIDEN, revealing more and more of machinery, banks of panels, fluttering gauges, until we r

A stainless steel room with no windows, the walls packed instrumentation.  The lights are dim and the air is frigi Occupying most of the floor space are rows of horizontal COMPARTMENTS, looking for all the world like meat lockers FOOM!  FOOM!  FOOM!  With explosions of escaping gas, the freezers pop open. Slowly, groggily, six nude men sit up.
Oh... God... am I cold...
Is that you, Roby?
I feel like shit...
Yeah, it's you all right. Now they are yawning, stretching, and shivering.
(groans)
Ohh... I must be alive, I feel dead.
You look dead.
The vampires rise from their graves. This draws a few woozy chuckles.
(shakes his fist in the air triumphantly)
We made it!
(not fully awake)
Is it over?
It's over, Hunter.
(yawning)
Boy, that's terrific.
(looking around with a grin)
Well, how does it feel to be rich men?
Cold! This draws a LAUGH.
Okay!  Everybody topside!  Let's get our pants on and get to our posts! The men begin to swing out of the freezers.
Somebody get the cat. Roby picks a limp cat out of a freezer.

This is a fantastic circular room, jammed with instrument are no windows, but above head level the room is ringed b viewscreens, all blank for the moment. There are seats for four men.  Each chair faces a console surrounded by a dazzling array of technology. STANDARD, ROBY, BROUSSARD, and MELKONIS are entering and seats.
I'm going to buy a cattle ranch.
(putting down the cat)
Cattle ranch!
I'm not kidding.  You can get one if you have the credit.  Look just like real cows, too.
All right, tycoons, let's stop spending our credit and start worrying about the job at hand.

Right.  Fire up all systems. They begin to throw switches, lighting up their consoles. room starts to come to life.  All around the room, colore flicker and chase each other across glowing screens.  The with the hum and chatter of machinery.
Sandy, you want to give us some vision?
Feast your eyes. Melkonis reaches to his console and presses a bank of swi strip of viewscreens flickers into life. On each screen, we see BLACKNESS SPECKLED WITH STARS.
(after a pause)
Where's Irth?
Sandy, scan the whole sky. Melkonis hits buttons.  On the screens the images all beg CAMERA MOVES IN ON ONE OF THE SCREENS, with its moving im starfield.

CLOSE SHOT OF A PANNING TV CAMERA.  This camera is remote turning silently on its base. CAMERA BEGINS TO PULL BACK, revealing that the TV camera the HULL OF SOME KIND OF CRAFT. When the pullback is finished, WE SEE THE FULL LENGTH OF "SNARK," hanging in the depths of interstellar space, aga background of glimmering stars.
Where are we?
Sandy, contact traffic control. Melkonis switches on his radio unit.
This is deep space commercial vessel SNARK, registration number E180246, calling Antarctica air traffic control.  Do you read me?  Over. There is only the HISS OF STATIC.
(staring at a screen)
I don't recognize that constellation.
Dell, plot our location. Broussard goes into action, punching buttons, lighting up instruments.
I got it.  Oh boy.
Where the hell are we?
Just short of Zeta II Reticuli.  We haven't even reached the outer rim yet.
What the hell? Standard picks up a microphone.
This is Chaz speaking.  Sorry, but we are not home.  Our present location seems to be only halfway to Irth. Remain at your posts and stand by. That is all.
Chaz, I've got something here on my security alert.  A high priority from the computer...
Let's hear it.
(punches buttons)
Computer, you have signalled a priority three message.  What is the message?
(a mechanical voice)
I have interrupted the course of the voyage.
What?   Why
I am programmed to do so if certain conditions arise.
Computer, this is Captain Standard. What conditions are you talking about?
I have intercepted a transmission of unknown origin.
A transmission?
A voice transmission.
Out here? The men exchange glances.
I have recorded the transmission.
Play it for us, please. Over the speakers, we hear a hum, a crackle, static...

head_text.subj: STRANGE, UNEARTHLY VOICE FILLS THE ROOM, SPEAKING AN ALIE

text: .  The bizarre voice speaks a long sentence, then falls silent. The men all stare at each other in amazement.
Computer, what language was that?
Unknown.
Unknown!  What do you mean?
It is none of the 678 dialects spoken by technological man. There is a pause, then EVERYBODY STARTS TALKING AT THE SA
(silencing them)
Just  hold it
hold it
(glares around the room)
Computer: have you attempted to analyze the transmission?
Yes.  There are two points of salient interest.  Number one: it is highly systematized, indicating intelligent origin.  Number two: certain sounds are inconsistent with the human palate.
Oh my God.
Well, it's finally happened.
First contact...
Sandy, can you home in on that beam?
What's the frequency?
Computer, what's the frequency of the transmission?
65330 dash 99. Melkonis punches buttons.
I've got it.  It's coming from ascension 6 minutes 32 seconds, declination -39 degrees 2 seconds.
Dell -- show me that on a screen.
I'll give it to you on number four. Broussard punches buttons.  One of the viewscreens flicke small dot of light becomes visible in the corner of the s
That's it.  Let me straighten it out. He twists a knob, moving the image on the screen till the the center.
Can you get it a little closer?
That's what I'm going to do. He hits a button.  The screen flashes and a PLANET APPEAR
Planetoid.  Diameter, 120 kilometers.
It's tiny!
Any rotation?
Yeah.  Two hours.
Gravity?
Point eight six.  We can walk on it. Standard rises.
Martin, get the others up to the lounge.
The entire crew -- STANDARD, ROBY, BROUSSARD, MELKONIS, H FAUST -- are all seated around a table, with Standard at
If it's an S.O.S., we're morally obligated to investigate.
Right.
I don't know.  Seems to me we came on this trip to make some credit, not to go off on some kind of side trip.
(excited)
Forget the credit; what we have here is a chance to be the  first men to contact a  nonhuman intelligence .
If there is some kind of alien intelligence down on that planetoid, it'd be a serious mistake for us to blunder in unequipped.
Hell, we're equipped --
Hell, no!  We don't know what's down there on that piece of rock!  It might be dangerous!  What we should do is get on the radio to the exploration authorities... and let them deal with it.
Except it will take 75 years to get a reply back.  Don't forget how far we are from the Colonies, Martin.
There are no commercial lanes out here.  Face it, we're out of range.
Men have waited centuries to contact another form of intelligent life in the universe.  This is an opportunity which may never come again.
Look --
You're overruled, Martin.  Gentlemen -- let's go.
The men are strapping in, but this time it is with grim d
Dell, I want greater magnification. More surface detail.  I want to see what this place looks like.
I'll see what I can do. He jabs his controls.  The image on the screen ZOOMS DOWN PLANET; but all detail quickly vanishes into a featureles
It's out of focus.
No -- that's atmosphere.  Cloud layer.
My God, it's stormy for a piece of rock that size!
Just a second. (punches buttons)
Those aren't water vapor clouds; they have no moisture content.
Put ship in atmospheric mode.
The great dish antenna on the SNARK folds down against th of the ship, and other parts flatten out, until the ship an aerodynamic form.
Dell, set a course and bring us in on that beam.

The SNARK's engines cough into life, and send it drifting distant dot that is the planetoid. CAMERA APPROACHES THE PLANETOID, until it looms large on turbulent, completely enveloped in dun-colored clouds. The SNARK drops down toward the surface.
Activate lifter quads.
Activated.  Vertical drop checked. Correcting course.  On tangential course now, orbiting. (brief pause as he studies his instruments)
Crossing the terminator.  Entering night side.
Beneath the orbiting SNARK, night's curtain rolls across Descending at an angle, the SNARK drops down into the thi of the planetoid.
Atmospheric turbulence.  Dust storm.
Turn on navigation lights.
Hydroplaning down through the pea-soup atmosphere, a set lights switches on, cutting through the dust, but hardly visibility.
Approaching point of origin.  Closing at 20 kilometers, 15 and slowing. Ten.  Five.  Gentlemen, we are directly above the source of the transmission.
What's the terrain down there?
Well, line of sight is impossible due to dust.  Radar gives me noise. Sonar gives me noise.  Infrared -- noise.  Let's try ultraviolet.  There. Flat.  It's totally flat.  A plain.
Is it solid?
It's... basalt.  Rock.
Then take her down.

Drop begins... now!  Fifteen kilometers and dropping... twelve...  ten... eight and slowing.  Five. Three.  Two.  One kilometer and slowing.  Lock tractor beams. There is a LOUD ELECTRICAL HUM and the ship shudders.
Locked.
Kill drive engines. The engines fall silent.
Engines off.
Nine hundred meters and dropping. 800.  700.  Hang on gentlemen.
The night-shrouded surface is a hell of blowing dust.  Th above it on glowing beams of light, dropping down slowly. Landing struts unfold like insect legs.
And we're... down.
The ship touches down, heavily; it rocks on huge shock ab
The whole ship VIBRATES VIOLENTLY FOR AN INSTANT -- then panels in the room flash simultaneously and the LIGHT'S G
Jesus Christ! The lights come back on again.
What the hell happened?
(hits a switch)
Engine room, what happened?
(over, filtered)
Just a minute, hold it, I'm checking.
Has the hull been breached?
Uh...  (scans his gauges)
No, I don't see anything.  We've still got pressure. There is a BEEP from the communicator.  Then:
(over, filtered)
Martin, this is Jay.  The intakes are clogged with dust.  We overheated and burned out a whole cell.
(strikes his panel)
Damn it!  How long to fix?
(into microphone)
How long to fix?
(over, filtered)
Hard to say.
Well, get started.
(over, filtered)
Right.  Talk to you.
Let's take a look outside.  Turn the screens back on. Melkonis hits buttons.  The screens flicker, but remain b
Can't see a blessed thing.
Only a few glittering lights distinguish the ship from th darkness around it.

head_text.subj: THE WIND MOANS AND SCREAMS. DUST BLOWS IN FRONT OF THE T

text: Kick on the floods.
A ring of FLOODLIGHTS on the ship come to life, pouring b out into the night. They illuminate nothing but a patch of featureless grey g clouds of blowing dust.  The wind shrieks.
Not much help. Standard stares at the dark screens.
Well, we can't go anywhere in this darkness.  How long till dawn?
(consults his instruments)
Well... this rock rotates every two hours.  The sun should be coming up in about 20 minutes.
Good!  Maybe we'll be able to see something then.
Or something will be able to see us. They all look at him.
The floodlights on the SNARK fight a losing battle agains darkness and the storm.  MAIN THEME MUSIC BEGINS, EXTREME

Gradually, the screen begins to lighten as the SUN RISES. silhouette of the SNARK becomes visible, like some strang crouching motionless on the barren plain.  The floods shu clouds of impenetrable dust shriek and moan, obscuring ev reducing the sunlight to a dull orange. END MAIN TITLES.

CLOSE ON A SCREEN - it shows nothing but swirling clouds dust. PULL BACK FROM SCREEN.  The men (Standard, Roby, Broussar Melkonis) are sitting and standing around the room, drink and staring at the screens, which reveal only the billowi
There could be a whole city out there and we'd never see it.
Not sitting on our butts in here, that's for sure.
Just settle down.  Sandy, you get any response yet?
(pulls off his earphones)
Sorry.  Nothing but that same damn transmission, every 32 seconds.  I've tried every frequency on the spectrum.
Are we just going to sit around and wait for an invitation? Roby gives Broussard a black look, then stabs a button on and speaks into the mike.
(into mike)
Hello, Faust!
(over, filtered)
Yeah!
How's it coming on the engines?
Faust is seated at an electronic workbench, brightly lit, into a wall intercom.
I never saw anything as fine as this dust... these cells are all pitted on a microscopic level.  I have to polish these things smooth again, so it's going to take a while.  Okay?
Yeah, okay. (puts down the mike)
Sandy... how far are we from the source of the transmission?
Source of transmission is to the northeast... about 300 meters.
Close...
Close enough to walk to!
Martin, would you run me an atmospheric?
(punches buttons and consults his panels)
10% argon, 85% nitrogen, 5% neon...  and some trace elements.
Nontoxic... but unbreathable. Pressure?
Ten to the fourth dynes per square centimeter.
Good!  Moisture content?
Zero.  Dry as a bone.
Any microorganisms?
Not a one.  It's dead.
Anything else?
Yeah, rock particles.  Dust.
Well, we won't need pressure suits, but breathing masks are called for. Sandy -- can you rig up some kind of portable unit that we can use to follow that transmission to its source?
No problem.
I volunteer for the exploration party.
I heard you.  You want to break out the side arms?

Standard, Broussard and Melkonis enter the lock.  They al boots, jackets, and pistols. Broussard touches a button and the inner door slides sile sealing them into the lock. They all pull on rubber full-head oxygen masks.
(adjusting the radio on his mask)
I'm sending.  Do you hear me?
Receiving.
Receiving.
All right.  Now just remember: keep away from those weapons unless I say otherwise.  Martin, do you read me?
Read you, Chaz.

Open the outer door. Ponderously, the outer lock door slides open.  ORANGE SUN into the lock, and clouds of dust swirl in.  We hear the WIND OUTSIDE. A mobile stairway slides out of the open hatchway, and cl hits the ground. Standard walks out into the storm, followed by the others

The three men trot down the gangplank to the surface of t Their feet sink into a thick layer of dust and loose rock The men huddle together, looking around.  The wind scream their clothes.  Nothing can be seen.
Which way, Sandy? Melkonis is fiddling with a portable direction-finder.
(pointing)
That way.
You lead. Melkonis walks into the blinding dust clouds, followed cl others.
Okay, Martin.  We're on our way.
Roby is the sole occupant of the bridge.  He is huddled o console, smoking a cigarette and watching three moving bl screen.
Okay, Chaz, I hear you.  I've got you on my board.
(over, filtered)
Good.  I'm getting you clear too. Let's just keep the line open.

The three men plough their way through a limbo of yellow shrieking wind.  With their rubbery masks and deliberate they look like deep-sea divers at the bottom of a murky o Melkonis leads the column, following the compass on the d finder.
Can't see more than three meters in any direction out here.  We're walking blind, on instruments. They wade on, following Melkonis.  Abruptly he halts.
What's wrong?
My signal's fading. He studies the direction finder.
Roby is listening intently to the dialogue from the helme
(over, filtered)
It's the dust, it's interfering...  His concentration is so great that he does NOT NOTICE HUN BEHIND HIM.
(over, filtered)
... Hold it, I've got it again.  It's over that way. Standing DIRECTLY BEHIND ROBY, Hunter speaks.
What's happening? Startled out of his wits, Roby GASPS and whirls around to
(startled silly)
Hell! Hunter stares at Roby, whose momentary terror dissolves i embarrassed anger.
The three men push their way through the storm.  Melkonis studies the direction finder.
It's close, real close.
How far?
We should be almost on top of it.  I just can't quite...  Suddenly, Broussard grabs Standard's arm and points.  The in the direction he is pointing.

Through the dense clouds of swirling dust we can just bar some kind of HUGE SHAPE. As we watch, the dust clears slightly, REVEALING A GROTES RISING FROM THE SHIP LIKE SOME GIGANTIC TOADSTOOL.  It is non-human manufacture.
They are struck dumb by the sight of the craft.  Finally, finds his voice.
Martin, uh, we've found it.
(sharply -- over, filtered)
Found what?
It appears to be some sort of spacecraft.  We're going to approach it. They start toward the alien ship.
(over, filtered)
There are no signs of life.  No lights... no movement...  Roby and Hunter are listening with hypnotic concentration
(over, filtered)
We're, uh, approaching the base.
A strangely shaped DOOR yawns open at the base of the shi sand have blown in, filling the lower part of the entranc With great caution, the men approach the entrance and gro
Appears to be a door hanging open, the entrance is clogged with debris.
Looks like a derelict.
Martin, we're going in.  I'm going to hold the conversation to a minimum from here on.

The doorway is a glowing geometric blur of light against spewing dust.  In the darkness of the chamber are huge, f shapes. Standard, Broussard and Melkonis appear silhouetted again doorway.  They switch on flashlight-like devices called " and step in. Carefully, peering around, they pick their way past the i machinery.
Air lock?
Who knows?
Let's try and find the control room. As they move their lights around, they can see that the w ceiling, and machinery are FULL OF HUGE, IRREGULAR HOLES.
Look at these holes.  This place looks like Swiss cheese. Broussard shines his light up into a huge hole in the cei
This hole goes up several decks -- looks like somebody was firing a military disintegrator in here. They all peer up the hole into darkness.

Climbing gear. Standard draws out a stubby spear gun with a graplon atta He aims it up into the hole and fires. The graplon is launched up into darkness, trailing a thin is a dull CLUNK, and the wire dangles.
I'll go first.

No, you'll follow me. Standard attaches the wire to a powered gear box on his c presses a button.  With a mechanical whine, he is pulled hole, using his feet for leverage where he can. Broussard attaches the wire to his own chest unit.

This chamber is totally dark as Broussard arrives at the hole. Standard stands with his flashlight/camera ("datastick") beam through the hanging dust. Broussard unclips himself from the climbing wire, then ra light.  At that moment, Melkonis arrives at the top of th THEIR LIGHTS SCAN THE ROOM.  The beams are clearly visibl of light in the floating dust.  They reveal heavy, odd sh Broussard stumbles over something.  He shines his light d It is a large, glossy urn, brown in color, with peculiar Broussard stands it upright.  It has a round opening in t empty. Suddenly, Melkonis lets out a grunt of shock.  Their ligh illuminated something unspeakably grotesque: A HUGE ALIEN SEATED IN THE CONTROL CHAIR. They approach the skeleton, their lights trained on it.

head_text.subj: GROTESQUE THING, BEARING NO RESEMBLANCE TO THE HUMAN FORM

text: Holy Christ...  Standard shines his light on the console at which the hid is seated.  He moves his light closer and peers at the pa
Look at this...  They approach.

Something has been scratched here...  into the veneer.  See? Traced raggedly onto the surface of the panel, as by the sharp instrument, is a small triangle: Hearing something, Broussard flashes his light across the beam scans the walls, it briefly touches on SOMETHING THA Melkonis convulsively yanks out his pistol.
Standard knocks his hand down.

Keep away from that gun! Standard shoulders himself in front of the others.  Then, begins to move toward the far side of the room. They approach a console on the wall, training their light There is a machine.  On the machine, a small bar moves st and forth, sliding noiselessly in its grooves.
Just machinery.
But functioning. Melkonis looks down at his direction finder.
That's where the transmission is coming from. He throws a switch on the direction finder -- with a crac hum, the UNEARTHLY VOICE fills their earphones.
A recording.  A damned automatic recording.

SINISTER ANGLE ON THE SNARK.  As we watch, the sunlight t of blood, and then the sun is down, leaving murky blackne wake.  The ring of floodlights on the ship flares into li combatting the darkness and the storm.

The entire crew is seated around the conference table, wa holographic pictures projected onto a screen.  These are by their "datasticks" (flashlight/cameras). Standard is commenting on the changing slides.
... This is the control room...  Two or three pictures click onto the screen in succession suited men standing against banks of machinery.
... Some details of the control room...  The SKELETON appears on the screen.  The men react with m
... This is the skeleton... another view of the skeleton... the transmitting device...  The triangle that was cut into the alien's console appear
... This is a closeup of the triangle we found scrawled on the console in front of the skeleton...  Standard changes the slide.  The screen goes white.
... And that's it. He turns off the projector and brings the lights up.
Phenomenal.  Staggering.
We've got to go back and take a lot more pictures, holograph everything .
And bring back as much physical evidence as possible, too.  The rest of the skeleton.  Some of the machinery.  Written records, if there are any. Roby is slumped in his chair.  He has said nothing.
Martin?
I agree.  This is the single most important discovery in history.
But?
What killed it?
Hell, that thing's been dead for years.  Maybe hundreds of years.  The whole planet's dead.
The way I figure it, they landed here for repairs or something, then they couldn't take off again.  Maybe the dust ruined their engines.  They set up an S.O.S. beacon, but nobody came.  So they died.
He died.
What?
Not  they
he
They all turn to look in the direction of Roby's nod.  CA OVER TO REVEAL THE ALIEN SKULL SITTING ON A TABLE.
... There was only one skeleton. There is a moment of silence.
Jay... how's it coming on the repairs?
Well... I'm going to have to blow the engines out...
And when will you be ready to do that?
Oh -- I'm not near ready yet.
Then why the hell are you sitting around here?
Right. The men rise and begin to disperse, but Roby remains seat thought, staring at the skull.  Melkonis lingers in the r
And there sits man's first contact with intelligent life in the universe.
ANGLE ON THE SHIP, its spotlights cutting into the gloom.

A room throbbing with power, enormous pulsing engines cap releasing unimaginable energies. Faust has a complicated arrangement set up at the base of engines, with spotlights on it.  He is wearing goggles an
You ready up there?
Broussard and Melkonis are seated at their consoles, conv Faust while they watch their instruments.
Sure, we're ready.
Okay.  I'm going to start the extraction procedure now. He pauses to wipe his brow.

Roby is alone in the room, slumped into a chair, watching photographic slides on the screen.  He is clicking slowly He stops on an angle of the skeleton, and stares at it. The alien's misshapen skull is sitting on the table next picks it up, holds it up to the screen for comparison, an Standard appears in the doorway.
Alas, poor Yorick. Roby STARTS, puts down the skull.  Standard sits at the t
(nodding at the screen)
Find anything we missed?
(shrugs)
I don't even know what I'm looking for.
Still worried?
Oh well... you know me.
I've always respected your opinion, Martin.  If something worries you, it worries me. Roby reaches over and changes the slide, to the one of th DRAWN TRIANGLE ON THE ALIEN CONTROL PANEL.
What would you say that was supposed to mean?
Well... it's obviously intentional...  some kind of attempt at communication... maybe it's a symbol that means something to them...
But why draw it on the wall? Roby switches off the projector, sits up, and rubs his fa He rises and goes to the coffee machine.
(picking a hair out of the coffeepot)
This ship is full of cat hair.
Tell you what, Martin.  As soon as the engine's fixed -- BEEP!  The communicator interrupts Standard.  He leans ac presses the button.
This is Chaz.
(over, filtered)
Chaz, this is Dell.  Can you come topside for a minute?
What's up?
(over, filtered)
Well, the sun just came up again, and it seems the wind's died down. It's as clear as a bell outside. There's something I think you ought to see.
I'm on my way. He and Roby head for the door.
Broussard is alone in the control room when Standard and
What is it?
Take a look.
The dust no longer blows.  The day is crisp, clear, and s
I was scanning the horizon to see what I could pick up.  Look there, on that screen.
What is it, I can't -- BLIP!  Broussard enlarges the image. The screen now shows a TAPERING STONE PYRAMID on the hori They all stare at the image for a long moment.  The silho

head_text.subj: PYRAMID IS INSTANTLY SUGGESTIVE OF THE SCRAWLED TRIANGLE

text: ship. Standard presses the nearest communicator and speaks into
This is Chaz.  All hands topside. Now.
ANGLE ON A VIEWSCREEN.  It shows the PYRAMID on the horiz PULLS BACK to reveal all the men, sitting and standing ar room.
Doesn't seem much doubt about it, does there?
That creature sure must have considered it important... using his last strength to draw it...
Maybe they built it.
As what?
A marker for buried instrumentation?
Or a mass grave.
Maybe the rest of the crew is in there -- in some kind of suspended animation, waiting to be rescued.
It wasn't necessarily built by them. On the screens, a puff of DUST blows in front of the pyra
Here comes the dust again.
WITH A SHRIEK, THE DUST STORM RETURNS, completely obscuri
Well, does anyone else agree with Martin that we should  not explore it? Everyone looks around the room, but no one volunteers.
Then the sooner we get moving, the better.

LONG SHOT OF THE STONE PYRAMID, dust blowing in front of crumbling, ancient edifice, made of eroded grey stones, w tapering toward the top. Standard, Broussard, and Melkonis, wearing the protective approach the pyramid.  As they draw near, it becomes clea pyramid is roughly 50 feet tall.
We can't make out any details or features yet... but it's definitely too regular for a natural formation...
Roby and Hunter are present.  They are listening to Stand THE RADIO.
(over, filtered)
... There's one thing I can say for sure though...  BUZZZZZ!  Standard's voice is DROWNED OUT BY STATIC.
Now what's wrong?
I've completely lost their signal.
Can you get them back?
I'm trying.
The three men come to the base of the massive structure. have piled thickly around the crumbling, grey stones that base.
This looks ancient.
Can't tell -- these weather conditions could erode anything, fast. They walk around the base.
There's no entrance.
Maybe the entrance is buried.  Could be under our feet.
Maybe there  is no entrance; the thing may be solid.
Well, there ought to be some way we can get through to them -- The INTERCOM BEEPS.  Faust's voice is heard.
(over, filtered)
Sorry to interrupt, but I'm gonna charge up the engines for a minute, okay?

Yeah, okay.  Go ahead. A LOUD, POWERFUL THROBBING BEGINS, drowning out all other the engines are tested. A light on Roby's panel is FLASHING.  We can see that it COMPUTER ALERT. Irritably, Roby throws the switch.
Yes!
I have a temporary sequence on the monitor --
Hold it, I can't hear a damn thing! He puts an earphone to his ear and switches the computer'
Go ahead! There is a PAUSE while Roby listens to the computer.  His
You mean... you've translated it? Another PAUSE as he listens to the earphone.
Well come on, come on!  What does it say? Another PAUSE.  Roby's face changes; he looks CHILLED TO mouth works. Abruptly, THE ENGINES SHUT OFF, LEAVING A RINGING SILENCE
(looking over at Roby)
What?  What was that?
The computer just translated the goddamn message.  It's not an S.O.S. It was a warning.
Maybe we can get in by the top.
You want to try?
Sure. Broussard takes out the graplon-gun, and fires the hook u top of the pyramid.  It catches.  He clips himself to the

You guys just wait down here till I say it's okay to come up. Broussard turns on the climbing device, and begins to wal of the pyramid. OMINOUS ANGLES showing Broussard climbing the pyramid, th blowing, the wind shrieking.
The peak of the pyramid is in extreme disrepair.  Broussa the top and clings to the jagged, crumbling stones.
There's a hole at the top.
Can we come up?
(over, filtered)
No, it's too small, only room enough for one person.
Can you see anything in the hole?
Broussard leans over and looks into the hole.  He sees on Freeing one arm, he unclips his datastick from his belt, the "flashlight" function, and shines it down into the ho
I can see... partway down.  It just goes down like a stovepipe.  Smooth walls.  I can't see the bottom -- light won't reach.
Faust comes trotting up the steps, a questioning look on
Yes?  What is it?
Jay, we've got a problem.  I was wondering if there was any way you could shortcut the repairs and give us immediate takeoff capability.
(quickly)
Why, what's wrong?
The computer's translated the alien signal, and it's kind of alarming.
What do you mean?
It couldn't translate the whole thing, only three phrases.  I'll just read it to you the way I got it: (reads from a strip of paper)
(looks up at the others)
And that's all it could translate.
Hanging from the lip of the hole, Broussard is unclipping his belt.
(over, filtered)
Dell, you want to come down, we can figure out where to go from here.
No, I want to go in.
Standard and Melkonis exchange a glance.
Okay, Dell, but just for a preliminary look-around.  Don't unhook yourself from your cable.  And be out in less than ten minutes.

Right. Broussard has rigged a tripod across the mouth of the hol unspools a couple feet of wire from the device, and attac of it to his chest unit. He climbs over the lip and drops into the hole.  He is no the wire, with his head and shoulders out of the hole.
Okay, I'm in the mouth of the chimney now, and I'm starting down.
(over, filtered)
Take care. Broussard activates the climbing unit and lowers himself hole.
Bracing his feet against the rough stone wall of the vert Broussard switches on his datastick and points it down in depths. The beam penetrates only thirty feet or so, then is lost

It's noticeably warmer in here.  Warm air rising from below. He starts down, paying out the line and moving down in sh pushing off each time with his feet. He stops to catch his breath.  His breathing rasps loudly helmet. A little sunlight filters down from above.  Looking up, h mouth of the hole, a glowing spot of light. Standard's voice comes over his earphones.
(over, filtered)
Are you okay in there?
(gasping for breath)
Yeah, I'm okay.  Haven't hit bottom yet.  Definitely a column of warm air rising; it keeps the shaft clear of dust.
(over, filtered)
What was that Dell, I lost you, do you read me?
Yeah, but this is hard work.  Can't talk now. He kicks off and continues down, taking longer and longer gains confidence. Pausing for a moment to regain his breath, he shines the instruments.
I'm way below ground level.
What'd he say?
I couldn't make it out -- too much interference.
Roby and Hunter.
I'm getting nowhere.  The whole area around the pyramid is dead to transmission.  I think we should go after them.
No.
What do you mean, no?
We're not going anywhere.
But they don't know about the translation!  They could be in danger right now.
We can't spare the personnel.  We've got minimum takeoff capability right now.  That's why Chaz left us on board.
Why, you chickenshit bastard --
Just can that crap!  I'm in command here till Chaz returns!  And nobody's leaving this ship!
Broussard resumes his downward climb.  SUDDENLY, HIS FEET PURCHASE AS THE WALLS OF THE SHAFT DISAPPEAR. The tunnel has reached its end.  Below him is an unfathom cavernous space.
(huffing and puffing)
Tunnel's gone -- cave or something below me -- feels like the tropics in here; air is warm and humid...  (consults his instruments)

... high oxygen content, no dust, it's completely breathable -- Puffing with exertion, he releases his purchase on the st begins to lower himself on power.  Now he is dangling fre spinning slowly on the wire as the chest unit unwinds. Finally, his feet hit bottom.  He grunts in surprise and his balance.

Broussard is standing on a dusty stone floor, with a feeb sunlight shining down around him from the tunnel above. solid darkness. He flashes his datastick around.  The beam reveals that h stone room.  STRANGE HEIROGLYPHICS are carved into the wa a primitive, religious appearance.  Row after row of pict from floor to ceiling, some epic history in an unknown la religious symbols dominate one wall. Spaced at intervals are stylized stone statues, depicting monsters, half anthropoid, half octopus.

It's unbelievable!  It's like some kind of tomb... some primitive religion!  Hey, is anybody there?  Do you read me?  Standard! Annoyed, Broussard yanks off his breathing goggles, and l hanging around his neck.  He takes a deep breath of the w
Standard and Melkonis are standing around nervously.
If we don't hear from him soon, I think we better go in after him.
Sun will be down in a minute.
Face bare, Broussard approaches the center of the room, w dominated by a large, broad pedestal.  On the pedestal ar

head_text.subj: LEATHERY URNS OR JARS, EXACTLY LIKE THE ONE BROUSSARD STU

text: He walks around the urns, studying them.  They all have s shines his light on one of them; then he lays his gloved He lifts his mask radio to his lips.

I don't know if you can hear me, but the place is full of large bottles or jars, just like the one we found on the other ship -- except these are all sealed.  Also they're soft to the touch. He peers more closely at the leathery object.
Another funny thing -- I just put my hand on it, and now there are these raised areas appearing where my fingertips were.
THE SUN DROPS BELOW THE HORIZON, throwing the landscape i Standard and Melkonis switch on their lights.
Let's go. He attaches his chest unit to the wire and starts up.

Broussard is moving his light along the rows of heiroglyp wall.  They depict stylized drawings of strange monsters. He pauses to quickly change the film clip in his datastic turns back to the "urn" he was examining -- BUT NOW THERE THE TOP OF IT. He shines his light on the floor at the base of the "urn. the "lid" -- the stopper that had filled the hole.  He pi studies it.  It appears more organic than artificial; the surface is spongy and irregular. Then he turns the light to the now-open "urn." He bends over the mouth of the "urn" shining the light in

head_text.subj: SHOCKING VIOLENCE, A SMALL, OCTOPUS-LIKE THING LEAPS OUT
ITSELF TO HIS FACE, WRAPPING ITS TENTACLES AROUND HIS HEA

text: With a MUFFLED SCREAM, he launches himself backward, tear thing with his hands.
The dust blows and howls as Standard and Melkonis arrive lights bobbing in the darkness.
(puffing with exertion)
Here's his line.  We can haul him out of there if we have to.
It'll yank him right off his feet if he's not expecting it.  The line could get tangled in something.
But what can we do?  He's out of radio contact.
Maybe we should just wait a few more minutes. Standard hesitates, clinging to the lip of the hole.
(making up his mind)

No, I told him to be out in ten minutes.  It's been much longer. Let's get him out of there. Standard pulls himself up and crouches precariously on th tunnel.  He begins to fiddle with the winch mechanism fro Broussard's line dangles.

The line's slack.  Christ, do you think the idiot unhooked himself? He switches on the winch motor.  With a whine, it begins line in.  After a moment, the line TIGHTENS WITH A JERK - motor slows down, laboring under the added weight.
There, it caught!
Is it still coming up, or is it hooked on something?
No, it's coming.
Can you see anything? Standard shines his light down into the hole.

No, I can't see far enough.  The line's moving, though. For a moment, the two men hang to the narrow top of the p saving their strength, while the line reels in and the wi Then Standard shines his light back down in.
I can see him!  Here he comes! The winch begins to LABOR HEAVILY.
Get ready to grab him! Broussard appears at the top of the pit, dangling limply wire.  Standard reaches for him -- then RECOILS SHARPLY.
Look out
There's something on his face
Melkonis attempts to come to his aid.
What is it
Don't touch him, watch it

In their panic and confusion, the men teeter momentarily, regain their balance.  They shine their lights on Broussa He appears to be completely unconscious -- AND THE OCTOPU STILL WRAPPED AROUND HIS FACE, MOTIONLESS.
Oh God, oh God no.
Help me -- I'm going to try to get it off. With his gloved hands, Standard grasps the tentacled mess pull it from Broussard's head.
It won't come -- it's stuck.
What is it?
How the hell should I know?  Come on, give me a hand, let's get him out of there! The two men grapple with Broussard's limp body, lifting h hole.
Roby and Hunter are sitting moodily, silent.  There is a while nothing is said, then:
I've got 'em!  They're back on my screens!
(leaps to his feet)
How many?
Three blips!  They're coming this way! Roby grabs a microphone.
(into mike)
Hey, can you guys hear me?
(over, filtered)
Yeah, we hear you!  We're coming back!
Thank Christ!  We lost you!  Listen, there's been a new development --
(over, filtered)

Can't talk now; Broussard's injured. We'll need some help getting him into the ship. Roby collapses into a chair, suddenly limp with apprehens feared something like this all along, and now it has begu
(to himself)
Oh no.
(into intercom)
Jay, this is Cleave!  Meet me at the main air lock! Hunter dashes from the room. Roby remains where he is, seated at his console.  He is s mind racing.  CAMERA MOVES IN ON HIS FACE.
Hunter comes racing down the steps and hurries up to the door. He presses the wall intercom.
(into intercom)
Martin, I'm by the inner lock door! I'll wait here for you to let them in!
(strangely quiet)
Right.
Faust comes running up, covered with grime.
What the hell's going on?
Don't know -- Broussard got hurt somehow.
Hurt!  How?
Don't know -- maybe we'll be real lucky and he just broke his neck. (a beat)
I knew we shouldn't of come down here.
Roby is seated alone in the room, listening to the transm Standard and Melkonis.
(over, filtered)
Martin, are you there? Roby leans forward and speaks into the microphone.
Here, Chaz.
(over, filtered)
We're coming up now, open the outer lock door.
Chaz -- what happened to Broussard?
(over, filtered)
It's some kind of organism, it's attached itself to him.  Let us in. Roby does not reply.
(over, filtered)
You hear me, Martin?  Open the outer door.
Chaz, if it's an organism, and we let it in, the ship will be infected.
(over, filtered)
We can't leave him out here, open the door.
(urgently)
Chaz, listen to me -- we've broken every rule of quarantine.  If we bring an organism on board, we won't have a single layer of defense left.
(over, filtered)
Martin, this is an order!  Open the door! Hating it, Roby leans forward and throws the switch.
A RED LIGHT goes on, on a console on the wall.  The whine servo is heard, followed by a solid metallic CLUNK.

Outer door's open. After a moment, they hear the motor sound again, followed CLUNK.  The outer door has closed again.  The red light g The inner door slides open, and Standard and Melkonis sta carrying the sagging body of Broussard.  A cloud of choki follows them out of the lock.
(pulling off his mask)
You men stay clear, there's a parasite on him. Hunter and Faust RECOIL.
Oh -- God -- oh --
Is it alive?
I don't know but don't touch it. Give us a hand here, let's get him up to the Autodoc. Hunter and Faust move in carefully to help with the limp

One of them flicks on the lights as they come shuffling i medical room, carrying Broussard. Revealed is a rather small cubicle whose walls are lined machinery.  The principle item of interest is a mechanize which rests in a cradle and slides in and out of a slot i
Help me, come on, let's get him up here. They slide the man onto the bunk.
That thing, God almighty, didn't you try to get it off him?
It wouldn't come. Standard yanks off his gloves.

Medical gloves. They pull thin elastic gloves from a dispenser in the wal them on. Gingerly, they approach Broussard. Standard places his hands on the octopus-thing that is sl on Broussard's face.  He grasps the tentacles in his hand pull it free.
It's really on there tight.
Here, let me try. Faust takes a pair of pliers from a rack, and carefully g of one of the tentacles.  Squeezing tightly, he leans bac weight.
(grabbing Faust's hands)
Stop it, you're tearing his face. A trickle of blood begins to ooze down Broussard's cheek.
It's not coming off -- not without his whole face coming off too.

Let's let the machine work on him. Efficiently, they strip Broussard naked, then Standard pr couple of switches on the wall.  The machine lights up, a is sucked into the slot in the wall. He is visible inside.  The machine immediately sprays a c disinfectant on him, then sterilizes him with a blinding A bank of video monitors pops on, revealing X-ray images parts of his body.  Sensors begin to scan, relays chatter ROBY APPEARS IN THE DOORWAY. Standard turns and looks at him.  For a long moment, the each other, then STANDARD STEPS FORWARD AND SLAPS ROBY AC FACE. The others are shocked.
Hey now, what is this?
Ask him.
(slowly puts his hand to his cheek)
I understand why you did that.
Good.
He wouldn't open the lock; he was going to leave us out there.
Yeah... well, maybe he should have.  I mean, you brought the goddamn thing in here.  Maybe  you deserve to get slapped.
(embarrassed)
Excuse me, I've got work to do. Faust exits.
I keep my mouth pretty much shut, but I don't like hitting.
(to Standard)
I guess I had it coming.  Let's call it settled. After a hard stare at Roby, Standard gives him a curt nod his attention to the machinery.
(slowly)
Would somebody fill me in?
He went into the pyramid alone.  We lost radio contact with him.  When we pulled him out, it was on his face. It won't come off, not without injuring him.
Where did it come from?
He's the only one that knows that.
How does he breathe? They study the monitors.
Blood's thoroughly oxygenated.
Yeah, but how?  His nose and mouth are blocked.

Let's look inside his head. Standard punches some buttons, and on the monitors, a kin image in vivid colors appears, depicting Broussard's HEAD TORSO. The parasite is clearly visible on Broussard's face.  In creature is a maze of complicated biology.  But the shock that, in X-ray, we can see that Broussard's jaws are forc and THE PARASITE HAS EXTRUDED SOME KIND OF LONG TUBE, WHI INTO HIS MOUTH AND DOWN HIS THROAT, ending near his stoma
Look at that.
What is it -- I can't tell anything --
It's some kind of organ -- it's inserted some kind of tube or something down his throat.
(turning sick)
Oh... God...  Hunter bends over and RETCHES.
I think that's how it's getting oxygen to him.
It doesn't make any sense.  It paralyzes him... puts him into a coma... then keeps him alive.
We can't expect to understand a life form like this.  We're out of our back yard.  Things are different here.
Well, can't we kill it?  I mean, we can't leave the damn thing on him.
We don't know what might happen if we tried to kill it.  At least right now it's keeping him alive.
How about cutting it off?  We can't pull it loose, but we can cut off everything but the bottom layer, where it's stuck to his face.

You're right... we can't stand here and do nothing. Standard picks up his dusty breathing mask and pulls it o Then he pulls back on his bulky gloves.  Finally, he pres and Broussard slides back out of the booth.
(muffled in his mask)

Somebody give me a scalpel. Melkonis takes a glittering surgical blade from a slot in and carefully passes it to Standard. Clumsily because of the gloves, Standard manipulates the hand till he has a decent grip on it.  Then he flicks a l with his thumb.  The scalpel begins to hum. Standard advances on the parasite.  The others draw back Roby reaches over and draws yet a longer blade from the r holds it inconspicuously at his side. Standard bends over the parasite.  Carefully, he touches the extreme end of one of the tentacles, where it curves back of Broussard's head. Effortlessly, the electronic blade slides through the ali Immediately, a urine-like fluid begins to flow from the w
(muffled)

I've made an incision... it's not reacting... but some kind of yellowish fluid is leaking out of the wound...  The noxious-looking liquid drips down onto the bedding ne Broussard's head.  Instantly, it starts to hiss, and a th smoke curls up from the stain.
(muffled)

Hold it, this stuff's smoking! The others REACT nervously. By now, the yellow fluid has eaten a hole through the bun dripped down onto the floor below.  The metal floor begin and sizzle, and more smoke rises. The men start to COUGH.
God, that smoke's poisonous!
(pointing)

It's eating a hole in the floor! Abruptly, the men jostle their way out of the room and hu corridor outside, coughing their lungs out. Standard, who is masked, remains.  Frantically, he attemp bandage on the wound, but the fluid instantly melts the b in the process, some of the stuff gets on Standard's glov begin to smoke. Frantically Standard leaps back, pulling off the smoulder Then he runs out into the corridor and yanks off his mask
That stuff's eating right through the metal!  It's going to eat through the decks and right out through the hull! By this time Standard has started to run for the stairs.
Followed by the others, Standard frantically clangs down the level below.
There!  Look! A droplet of the fluid is sizzling on the ceiling.  It oo drips to the floor. It bubbles on the floor.
Jesus, what can we put under it? Standard and Hunter charge down the stairs to the level b
Standard and Hunter move cautiously down the corridor, lo the ceiling.
(pointing)
There.  Should be coming through about there.
Careful, don't get under it!
Roby and Melkonis crouch by the spot on the floor where t sizzles.
Christ, that stinks. Roby fishes a pen out of his pocket and probes into the h floor.
Seems to have stopped penetrating. Hunter comes charging up the steps.
What's happening up here?
I think it's fizzled out. Hunter approaches and looks.  Roby straightens up, starts pen back in his pocket, then changes his mind and stands the end.
I never saw anything like that in my life... except molecular acid.
But this thing uses it for  blood .
Hell of a defense mechanism.  You don't dare kill it. Standard comes up the stairs.
It's stopped?
Yes, thank heaven.
We're just plain lucky.  That could have gone right through the hull -- taken  weeks to patch it.
Reminded me of when I was a kid and the roof leaked -- everybody running for the pots and pans.
My God, what about Broussard? They turn and run up the stairs.
They all come into the room (Roby carrying the partially Broussard is still motionless on the bunk, with the thing
Did it get on him? Standard approaches and peers at Broussard's head.
No, thank God... just missed him.
Is it still dripping?
(examining it)
It appears to have healed itself.
It makes me sick to see him like that.
Isn't there some way we can get it off him?

I don't see how.  But let's do what we can for him. Standard presses a button, and Broussard slides back into diagnostic coffin.  He presses more buttons, and the disp again, showing different parts of Broussard's body.

I think we'd better get some intravenous feeding started.  God knows what that thing is leaching out of him. Standard operates some controls, and the machine begins t Broussard's body, sliding needles into him.
(studying the screens)
Look there, what's that stain on his lungs? The X-ray reveals a spreading dark blot in the vicinity o chest.  In the center, the stain is completely opaque.
It appears to be a heavy fluid of some sort... it blocks the X-rays...
That tube must be depositing it in him.
Could be some kind of venom, or poison...
This is horrible.
Hey!  what about the film?
What film?
Broussard had film in his datastick, didn't he?  We can see what happened to him.

Again we are watching slides in the darkened room.  This Roby, Melkonis, and Hunter are watching the sequence of p taken automatically by Broussard's datastick as he probed The camera reveals the "urns."  The climax of the sequenc comes when THE CREATURE LEAPS OUT OF THE "URN" TOWARD THE and after that the camera drops to a useless angle and pr show a series of meaningless blurs.  Then the reel ends.
That must have been when he got it.
The same thing must've happened to the creatures on the other ship...  except they took one of those jars on board, and opened it there.
(clicks back through the slides to a picture of one of the "urns")

At first I thought they were jars too, or artifacts anyway.  But they're not.  They're eggs, or spore casings.  Let's go back to the heiroglyphics. CLICKETYCLICKETYCLICK -- Melkonis accelerates through the blur, stopping at the one he wants -- which shows a strip heiroglyphs on the wall of the tomb.
I personally can't make any sense out of it...  CLICK.  CLICK.  Melkonis is changing the slides as they t different angles on the glyphs.
It's a crude symbolic language -- looks primitive.
You can't tell -- that kind of stuff could represent printed circuits...
That sounds a little fanciful...
Primitive pictorial languages are based on common objects in the environment, and this can be used as a starting point for translation...
What common objects?
Listen, hadn't somebody better check on Broussard?
(rising)
I'll do it.  The rest of you continue.
(rising)
I'll come with you.
Standard and Hunter come down the passageway.
You know, it's fantastic -- the human race has gone this long without ever encountering another advanced life form, and now we run into a veritable zoo.
What do you mean?

Well, those things out there aren't the same, you know -- the spaceship and the pyramid.  They're from different cultures and different races.  That ship just landed here -- crashed like we did.  The pyramid and the thing from it are indigenous.
How could anything be indigenous to this asteroid?  It's dead.
Maybe it wasn't always dead. They arrive at the infirmary.
The door slides open, and they step into the room.  Hunte the bed, and it slides out of the wall. THERE IS A LONG, HORRIFIED PAUSE.
It's gone. They rush to Broussard's prone form.  THE PARASITE IS GON FACE. Broussard is still unconscious, but he is breathing.  HIS COVERED WITH SUCKER MARKS.
Now we're in for it.
The door was closed.  It must still be in here. They immediately grow very tense.  Hunter starts edging t door.  Standard grabs his arm.
No, don't open the door.  We don't want it escaping.
(very nervous)
Well, what the hell good can we do in here?  We can't grab it -- it might jump on us --
Maybe we can catch it. Standard picks up a stainless steel tray with a lid.

As long as we're careful not to damage it...  Tray in one hand, lid in the other, Standard begins movin around the room.  There are very few places to hide. He bends down and peers under the bunk. As he is down on his hands and knees, WE SEE ONE TENTACLE THING, VIBRATING ON A LEDGE JUST ABOVE STANDARD. He rises, and HIS SHOULDER BRUSHES THE TENTACLE.  THE PAR THE FLOOR.
(leaping back)

Shit! But the thing is not moving.  It lies motionless on the f tentacles curled up.  Its color has faded to a dead-looki Without taking his eyes off the thing, Standard reaches b takes a long probe from the wall.  He prods the thing; it respond.
I think it's dead. With great care, he uses the probe to fish the motionless into the tray.  Then he quickly closes the lid.
Standard, Roby, and Melkonis have the parasite spread-eag stainless steel table, with a bright light on it.  It is Wearing gloves, Standard probes at the thing with an inst
Look at these suckers -- no wonder we couldn't get it off him.
Is that its mouth?
More likely that organ -- the tube- like thing -- fits up in there. With a pair of needle-nosed pliers, Standard fishes in th aperture.  Carefully, he extracts the end of the tube-org
Ugh. Suddenly, it starts to FALL APART IN THE PLIERS.

Quick -- it's decomposing -- gimme something to grab it with! It begins to SMOKE AND BUBBLE. Roby grabs a long pair of tongs from the wall and thrusts Standard -- who throws down the pliers, snatches the tong the thing in the tongs. It is smouldering and dripping acid on the floor.
Christ!  Let's get it out of here! Carrying the thing, he heads for the door.
The men run down the passageways, Standard carrying the d in the tongs.  It leaves little smoking droplets on the f
They come running up to the airlock.  Roby stabs the butt inner door slides open.  By the time Standard is in the l already on the intercom:
(shouts into intercom)
For Chrissake, open the main lock!
Roby stumbles in as the inner door closes; and with a hea thick surface door rumbles open.  Orange sunlight billows by the inevitable dust. Standard HURLS THE CARCASS OUT, tongs and all.
The parasite hits the ground and begins to sink into the smouldering and fuming.
The outer door rolls shut.
(slumping against the wall)

My God, it's lethal even when it's dead! Melkonis gets down on his knees and studies the small bur the floor. Standard opens the inner door and steps out into the corr he activates the wall intercom and punches out a combinat
(over intercom, filtered)
Yes?
How's Broussard?
(over, filtered)
He's running a fever.
Still unconscious?
(over, filtered)
Yes.
Can you do anything for him?
(over, filtered)
The machine will bring his temperature down.  His vital functions are strong.
Good. He switches off the intercom.
(suddenly exhausted)
I need some coffee. He turns and walks away.
The cat is strolling around as Roby and Melkonis drop int Standard draws a cup of coffee from the machine.
These day and night cycles are totally disorienting.  I feel like we've been here for days, but it's only been how long?
(stroking the cat)
About four hours.
(staring into his coffee cup)
I'm sorry to say it looks like you were right in the first place, Martin.  We never should have landed here.
Look, I'm not trying to rub anybody's nose in anything.  The important thing is just to get away from here as fast as possible.
I can't lean on Faust any harder -- he's been working non-stop on the engines.
If we knew exactly what happened to the beings on the other ship --
We do know that.
Yeah?
They never made it off the planet. The parasites won. This brings a CHILLY SILENCE.
Where did the parasites come from?
They seem native to the planet.  It's got an atmosphere and a dense gravity.  It's dead now, but once it must have been fertile.
No.  It's just too small to support fauna as big as the parasites.  If there were a native ecology, it would have to be microscopic.
Couldn't the pyramid have been built here by space travellers?
Too primitive.  It's a pre- technological construction.  That slab was engineered by an Iron-Age culture at best.
They're from a dead civilization; they're spores from a tomb.  God knows how long they've been here.
I think we better take another look at those heiroglyphs. Suddenly the door opens and Faust sticks his head in.  He with dirt and grime.
Hey, guess what?
What?
The engines are fixed.
The SNARK's engines cough and then with a ROAR BEGIN TO B STREAMS OF SUPERHEATED AIR, cutting through the tulgy dus The ship roars and vibrates like a huge beast, capable of power.
They are all at their posts.
Switch on tractor beams. There is a hair-tingling ELECTRICAL HUM which permeates t ship, and it begins to float, like a cork in water.
Lock tractor beams. The pitch of the hum changes, and the ship levels itself.
Retract landing struts.
The ship is hovering above the ground on beams of shimmer The landing struts fold up under the belly of the ship.
Take us up.
(into intercom)
Up one kilometer, Jay.
The SNARK begins to levitate up into the sky, on the beam
Switch on lifter quads. A POWERFUL, DEEP THROBBING BEGINS.  THE SHIP VIBRATES.
The hovering SNARK begins to accelerate through the choki atmosphere.
Engage artificial gravity. Roby throws a switch, and the ship LURCHES.
Engaged.
Let's take her into an escape orbit. The men get busy with switches.
I'm altering our vector now; should give us an easy escape velocity -- A HUGE TREMOR RUNS THROUGHOUT THE SHIP.
(in concert)
What was that? In answer, THE COMMUNICATOR BEEPS.
(over, filtered)
This dust is getting clogged in the intakes again!
Just hold us together till we're in space, that's all! The pitch of the engines changes, deepens.
The SNARK swoops up at an acute angle into the boiling cl Visibility is zero.
Faust is pulling on a gasmask, because the engine chamber to fill with dust.  He turns on a huge exhaust unit which suck up some of the dust.

On the screens, nothing but clouds.  Then, ANOTHER TREMOR THROUGH THE SHIP.  The men no longer speak; their express set, and sweating; they are watching their instruments. they mutter technical instructions to each other.
Abruptly the ship CLEARS THE TOP OF THE CLOUD LAYER AND B INTO STAR-SPRINKLED SPACE, trailing a wake of dust behind
They all CHEER.
(pounds his panel)
We made it!  Damn, we made it!
You bet we made it.  Martin, set course for Irth and accelerate us into stardrive.
With great pleasure. Roby begins to punch buttons.
I feel like an escapee from Hell.

The ship's speed is so great that there is perceptible mo universe all around. There is a strange corona effect which causes the stars a the ship to appear blue, and the receding ones to be red. redshift, made visible because of their incredible veloci
They are unstrapping.
That's the part that always makes me feel like I'm gonna puke -- when we accelerate into light speed.
Quit complaining; we're in space. They rise and head out of the room.
As they walk along.
I think the best thing to do with Broussard is to just freeze him as he is.  It'll arrest the progress of his disease, and he can get complete medical attention when we get back to the Colonies.
We'll have to go into quarantine, maybe for quite a while.
That's okay, he can remain in hypersleep until they're ready to treat him. They enter the infirmary.
As they enter the room, THEY ARE SHOCKED TO SEE BROUSSARD in BED -- AWAKE.
(hoarsely)
... Mouth's so dry... can I have some water...  Instantly, Roby brings him a plastic cup of water.  Brous down in a swallow.
More. Roby quickly fills a much bigger container and hands it t who greedily consumes the entire thing.  Then he sags, pa bunk.
(softly)
How do you feel, Dell?
(weakly)
Wretched.  What happened to me?
Don't you remember?
Don't remember nothing.  Can't hardly remember my name.
Are you in pain?
Not exactly, just feel like somebody's been beating me with rubber hoses for about six years. Melkonis laughs at this remark.  Broussard smiles faintly
Hell, you're in great shape, you've got your sense of humor back!
God I'm hungry.
Dell, what's the last thing you can remember?
... I don't know...
Do you remember the pyramid?
No.  Just some horrible dreams about smothering.  Where are we?
We're going home.  We're in hyperspace.
We're going into the freezers now.
I'm really starving; can we get some food before we go into the freezers?
(laughs)
I think that's a pretty reasonable request.
The entire crew is seated around the table, eating huge p greedily.  The cat eats from a dish on the table.
Boy do I feel a lot better.  It's a straight shot back to the Colonies, and then we can start taking bids on the paydirt.  Any bets on the top bid?
(chewing)
Well, we should at least be able to each buy our own planet. They all CHUCKLE.
I'm going to write a book about this expedition.  I'm going to call it "The Snark Log."
(stiffly)
The commander normally has first publication rights.
Maybe we could write it together.
First thing I'm going to do when we get back is eat some biological food.
What's the matter, you don't like this stuff?
Tastes like something you'd feed a chicken to make it lay more eggs.
Oh it's okay.  I've had better cag than this, but I've had worse too, if you know what I mean.
I kind of like it.
You like this shit?
It grows on you.
You know what they make this stuff out of?
(annoyed)
Yes, I know what they make it out of, so what?  It's food now.   You're eating it.
I didn't say it was bad for you, it's just kind of sickening, that's all.
Do we have to talk about this kind of crap at the dinner table? Suddenly, unexpectedly, BROUSSARD GRIMACES AND GROANS.
What's wrong?
(his voice straining)
I don't know... I'm getting these
The others stare at him in alarm.  Another GROAN is torn He clutches the edge of the table with his hands, his knu whitening.
Breathe deeply.
(screaming)

head_text.subj: OH GOD IT HURTS SO BAD

text: What Dell --  what
Broussard's face is screwed up into a mask of agony, and trembling violently from head to foot.
(incoherent shriek)
OhmygooaaAA

head_text.subj: A RED SMEAR OF BLOOD BLOSSOMS ON THE CHEST OF BROUSSARD'S
THEIR EYES ARE ALL RIVETTED TO BROUSSARD'S CHEST AS THE F
TUNIC IS RIPPED OPEN, AND A HORRIBLE NASTY LITTLE HEAD TH

text: Everybody SCREAMS and leaps back from the table.  The cat bolts. The disgusting little head lunges, comes spurting out of chest trailing a thick, wormlike tail -- splattering flui -- lands in the middle of the dishes and food on the tabl scurries away while the men are stampeding for safe groun When they finally regain control of themselves, it has es Broussard lies slumped in his chair, a huge hole in his c spouting blood.  The dishes are scattered and the food is blood and slime.
Oh, no.  Oh, no.
What was that?  What the Christ was that?
It was growing in him the whole time and he didn't even know it! Slowly, they gather around Broussard's gutted corpse.
That thing used him for an incubator!
A hatch slides open on the side of the ship, and Broussar body tumbles silently out. AN ELECTRONIC BASS DRUM BEATS A DIRGE as Broussard drifts eternity.
The entire remaining crew is walking toward the bridge.
We can't go into hypersleep with that thing running around loose.
We'd be sitting ducks in the freezers.
But we can't kill it.  If we kill it, it will spill all its body acids right through our hull and out into space.
Shit...
We'll have to catch it and eject it from the ship.
(sighs)

Well, I kind of hate to point it out, but all our supplies are based on us spending a strictly limited amount of time out of suspended animation... and as you know, we used up most of that time in harvesting.
We've got about a week left, right?
And then we run out of food and oxygen.
The water will still recycle.
We won't need it then.
All right, so that's what we've got. A week.  It's plenty of time.
But if we  haven't caught it in a week, then we have to go into the freezers anyway. They enter the bridge.
So does anybody have any suggestions?
We could put on our pressure suits and blow all the air out of the ship.  That would kill it.
No, we can't afford to lose that much oxygen.  We're going to have to flush it out.
How?
Room by room, corridor by corridor. No one likes this thought.
And what do we do when we find it?
We'll have to trap it somehow.  If we had a really strong piece of net, we could bag it.
We could cut a section out of that metallite netting.  It won't hold up to that acid, but aside from that it's pretty strong.
We have to avoid injuring it.  What we really need is some electric animal prods.
I think I could cobble something together.  A long metal rod with a battery in it.  Give it a hell of a shock.

Good.  Get on it.  But first, I'm issuing a standing order: from this moment forth, every one of us will wear protective garments, including helmets.  Let's get down to the locker and change. They start for the exit.
The SNARK continues on its way through the weird vortex o

Standard is walking purposefully along the corridor, alon garmented in an unusual outfit which makes him look like policeman, including clear plastic helmet. He reaches a corner and turns.  But this new passageway h gravity orientation -- Standard seems to be walking down wall. He makes yet another disorienting turn, and now he is wal down.  He reaches a set of steps and climbs up them -- or them.

Melkonis is seated in the dome, upside-down, peering down He also wears the protective suit. Standard, upside-down, climbs into the dome.  It is dark here, under the stars of interstellar space.  A few glowi provide the only illumination.
I thought I'd find you here.
I was thinking of a line from an old poem: "Water, water everywhere, but not a drop to drink."  All that space out there, and we're trapped in this ship.
That's the one about the albatross, right?

We can't even radio for help; the carrier wave wouldn't reach its destination till long after we'd died and turned to dust.  We are utterly, absolutely alone.  Can anybody really visualize such a scale of distances?  Halfway across Creation...
We came out there, we'll go back.  A long time by the clock, but a short time to us.
Time and space have no meaning out here.  We're living in Einsteinian equation.
I can see you're putting your spare time to good use. (leans forward and taps him on the knee)
Let me tell you something: you keep staring at hyperspace for long enough, they'll be peeling you off a wall.  I've seen it happen.
(smiles at him)
We're the new pioneers, Chaz.  We even have our own special diseases.
Come on -- let's go above and see how they're coming with the gear.
The whole crew has assembled.  Faust is unfolding several shimmering metallic netting. Hunter hands out five thin rods, like metal broom handles
These have portable generators in them.  They're insulated down to here -- just be careful not to touch the end. He demonstrates by touching the tip of one of the rods to object.  A blue spark leaps.
Might even incinerate the damn thing.
(sharply)
I hope not.
Don't worry, it won't damage it, it'll just give it a little incentive.
How do we locate the creature?
With these. He picks up a small portable unit.
Tracking device.  You set it to search for a moving object... It hasn't got much range, but when you get within a certain distance, it starts beeping. Standard takes the device and studies it.

These will be very useful.  At least we won't have to go digging around in closets with our bare hands.  All right, here's the battle plan: we're going to break into two teams and start systematically covering the ship.  Whoever finds it first, catches it in the net and ejects it from the nearest airlock.  Clear?
Even simple. Standard shoots him a vicious look, then continues:
For starters, let's make sure the bridge is safe. Faust takes the device and turns it on.  He scans it arou
It's clear.
All right -- Roby and Melkonis will go with Faust.  Hunter and I will make up the second team. They start doling out the equipment.
We'll all carry communicators.  We want to keep in constant touch.
Melkonis and Roby carry the net, while Faust walks direct carrying the tracking device.  He continually scans it fr side.
Nothing yet... nothing... we can move pretty fast as long as there's nothing on the tracker.
Standard and Hunter move silently along.  Standard is for double function, carrying one edge of the net and the tra
Roby's team is moving at a fairly brisk pace, when:
Hold it. Faust's tracker is BEEPING, and a small light flashes.
I've got something. Immediately, they grow very tense and start looking aroun
Where's it coming from?
(peers closely at tracker and frowns)
Machine's screwed up, I can't tell. Needle's spinning all over the dial.
Is it malfunctioning? Faust turns the tracker on its side, and the needle stabi
No, just confused.  It's coming from below us. They all look down at their feet.

Roby, Melkonis, and Faust come carefully down a set of cr stairs, into a drab, functional section of the ship. The corridors in this level are lit by rows of bare bulbs ceiling.  The effect is ugly and confining. They stop at the foot of the stairs and move into positio the net across the corridor.
Okay.
(looking at tracker and nodding down the passageway)
That way. They begin to walk down the passageway, footsteps clangin metal flooring.  It is extremely dark.
What happened to the lights?
Bulbs burned out, nobody bothered to replace 'em. They switch on the helmet lights.

head_text.subj: CAMERA FOLLOWS THEM AROUND A COUPLE OF TURNINGS, AND THEN

text: Hold it. They all stop quickly, almost stumbling.
(whispering)

It's within 4 meters. Roby and Melkonis heft the net, each keeping his prod in prod in one hand and tracker in the other, has the unplea approaching the source of the signal. He moves with great care, in a half crouch, ready to leap second, prod extended, constantly glancing at the tracker The tracking device leads him right up to a small hatch o wall. Behind his plastic mask, sweat is pouring down Faust's fa down the tracker and reaches for the little door.  He rai grasps the door handle, yanks it open, and jams the elect inside.

head_text.subj: WITH A NERVE-SHATTERING SQUALL, A SMALL CREATURE COMES FL
THE CABINET, EYES GLARING, CLAWS FLASHING.

text: Instinctively, they throw the net over it, but:
(very annoyed)
Oh, hold it! They open the net and release the creature.  IT IS THE CA spitting, it scampers away.
We're making fools of ourselves! Roby's COMMUNICATOR BEEPS.
(into communicator)
Yes!
(over, filtered)
We've got it up here!  It's trapped! Get up here fast!
Where are you?
(over, filtered)
Food-storage room!
We're coming! They dash for the stairs.
Roby, Faust, and Melkonis charge down the hallways until at:
Standard and Hunter are waiting for them, in hysterics.
We saw it inside and slammed the door on it!  It's in there now! On the other side of the door, CRASHING AND BANGING can b
What's it doing, having a seizure?
It started crashing around right after we locked it in.
Now what?
I guess we open the door and net it.
I hate to open that door. Again the thing can be heard CRASHING AROUND INSIDE.
It looks completely different from the first one -- it's more like a worm with legs... and tentacles.
Well we better do something.
Maybe we don't have to.  It's trapped in there.  We could just leave it in there all the way back to Irth.
(snaps)
Don't be an idiot.
I know what we can do.  We can pump poison gas into the room and kill it.  Through those ventilator slots there. He indicates a row of slots in the bottom of the door.
Hey, wait a minute!  That's all our food supplies in there!  We can't pump poison gas all over them!

Once we kill the thing we won't need the food any more -- we can go straight into hypersleep.  Also, it sounds like that thing is already doing a pretty good job on our supplies; it may be fouling them all.
You win.
Somebody gimme a hand, I'll get the stuff.

CAMERA PULLS BACK TO REVEAL THAT they are fastening a lar shaped device over the ventilator grill at the bottom of This funnel is attached to a thick hose, which runs back metal tank with pressure gauges.
Get those masks on. They pull on gas masks.
This stuff's deadly -- I hope we know what we're doing.

Go ahead, Jay. Faust turns on the machine.  It begins to throb as it pum through the hose and into the room. Immediately, THE CRASHING NOISES RISE IN CRESCENDO, AND T BE HEARD SCREECHING AND SQUEALING. Then the sounds stop altogether.
Shut it off. Faust shuts off the pump.
Now what?
What do you think?  Now we go in. Standard steps to the door and opens it.  A thick cloud o out.
The room is thick with the poison gas.  The men look like their gasmasks. The food packages are ripped to shreds, and foodstuffs ar all over the floor.
Looks like he helped himself. Carefully, the men poke through the garbage, net and prod Then Hunter points.
God damn it. They all look where he is pointing.  In the wall, A VENTI HAS BEEN RIPPED OPEN.
It escaped. They move to the shredded ventilator and shine their ligh
Where does that go?
All over the ship; we'll have to check the charts to know for sure.
Then let's go and do it. They head for the door.
Have we got any food at all left in the ship? They slam the door shut and seal it.
The screens are showing them a schematic of the ship's sy ventilator shafts.
That one section of the ventilator shaft has only two outlets -- you notice?  The food storage room on one end --
-- And the cooling unit on the other.
So it's trapped in between -- now we have to drive it out.
Poison gas...
We can't pump poison gas down into the cooling unit!  It'll flood the whole ship!
The only other thing I can think of is for somebody to crawl in there and flush it out.
Are you  crazy
The man would need protection, obviously -- as well as some way to drive the thing before him.
How about a flamethrower?  That wouldn't poison the air.
So one of us goes into the airshaft and drives the thing along --
While the rest of us wait down in the cooling unit with the net.
Sounds like a rough one.
Got a better idea? Hunter shrugs.
So the only question left is: who gets to crawl down the airshaft?

Let's be democratic. He tears five small sheets of paper from a pad on his con of them, he draws a large X.  Then he wads each piece of tiny little ball. He rolls the paperballs between his hands and tosses them like dice.

Martin, take one. Roby picks one up and unfolds it.  It is blank. Melkonis picks up another and opens it.  Again blank. Faust picks up a ball, and Standard immediately picks his are both blank. They all look at Hunter, who has not yet unfolded his.
Open it up, Cleave.
Hunter is strapping on an oxygen mask and a flame thrower helping him. Finally, Faust hands him a tracking device.
Well, uh... good luck.  I hope you won't need me, but if you do, I'm here.
(grimly)
Right. Hunter turns and climbs into the ventilator opening, whic large enough to crawl through.
It is completely dark in the shaft.  Hunter reaches up an helmet light.  Then he switches on his radio.
Hey, do you guys read me down there?
Standard, Melkonis and Roby are spreading out the net.  W of huge cooling plants, and their hair ruffles.  Large ai off in different directions.
Yeah, we're getting into position.

Okay, I'm starting now. He begins to crawl forward into the narrow metal tunnel. corner. After a couple more tight turns, THE TRACKER SUDDENLY BEE Hunter twitches.  He raises his flamethrower and FIRES A DARKNESS.  It roars loudly in the confined tube, and the heats up.  Smoke drifts back into his face.  He begins to
Roby points to a large rectangular opening in one wall.
(pointing)
There.  That's where it's got to come out. He throws a switch, and a large metal panel rises and sea opening.
That's a flip-flop gate to channel the air, but we can use it to trap the thing.
Right now let's keep it closed. Melkonis is setting up a little portable unit with a scre screen shows a section of the ship's schematic.
I've got Hunter... and something else as well, in front of him.
Are they close?
They're on the next level up.
Let's get moving with this net. They lift the net up, holding it in front of the opening.

Hunter is still crawling on hands and knees.  Up ahead, h the shaft takes an abrupt downward turn. He crawls toward the down angle, then fires another blast flamethrower. Then he starts crawling down, head first. When he is nearly upside-down, the shaft takes yet anothe which puts him into a nearly impossible position, almost Then the tracker starts BEEPING LIKE CRAZY. Frantically, he fumbles the flamethrower around, but the narrow -- it is difficult maneuvering.  He hears a HISSIN ahead, and claws scrambling on metal. Then he has the weapon into position, and sprays another flaming burst toward the sound.
Melkonis is staring at his screen.
They're getting pretty close now.
All right, then -- when it gets to the other side of the door, you sing out, then drop the door.  Okay?
Okay.
(to Roby)
And you and I will bag it, and then we'll take it to the ventral air lock, got it?
(tensely)
Uh-huh.
Hunter is huddled against a wall of the shaft, clutching flamethrower.
(whispers)
Hey, you guys.
(into communicator)
Yes!
(whispering)
I don't think this shaft goes on too much farther... anyway it's getting pretty hot in here...
(into communicator)
Okay, our screens show you as being near to the opening.  We'll open it up, then we'll cue you and you can start blasting.  That'll drive it right out.  You don't have to go any farther.
Good. He readies the flamethrower.
Okay, get ready. He and Roby heft their respective ends of the net, crouch the small creature when it darts out.  Melkonis picks up prod.
Open the vent, Sandy. Melkonis reaches over and throws the switch.  The metal g down, opening up the shaft.

head_text.subj: A SIX-FOOT MONSTROSITY STANDS IN THE OPENING. GHASTLY BE
IMAGINATION, SQUAMOUS, COVERED WITH TENTACLES, IT HOPS DO
OVER-SIZED BIRD AND GRABS MELKONIS IN RAZOR-SHARP TENTACL

text: Melkonis lets out a horrible shriek, and the thing grabs one claw and TWISTS IT OFF LIKE A MAN PULLING THE HEAD OF

head_text.subj: THEN THROWS IT TO THE FLOOR WITH AN AUDIBLE
CLUTCHING MELKONIS' BODY TIGHTLY AGAINST ITSELF, IT TURNS
DOWN THE HALL. MELKONIS' HEADLESS BODY IS STILL KICKING
AS THE MONSTER LEAPS HEAD-FIRST INTO ANOTHER AIR SHAFT.

text: Standard and Roby are left standing in shock.  After a mo climbs out of the shaft.
What happened?  Where is it? They break from their paralysis, and run toward the openi creature just leaped into.  It is another shaft, going do darkness.
(awed)
How did it get so  big
By eating our food supplies.
Where's Melkonis?
Faust is still waiting.
(into his communicator)
Hey, are you guys still there? What's going on?
(over, filtered)
Meet us on the bridge.  Be careful -- it's  huge now.
Right. Faust lets himself out of the food storage room and caref the door behind him.
Standard, Roby and Hunter are rapidly ascending toward th
You mean his body was still kicking when it ran off with him?
It was horrible -- horrible.  Like a chicken.
Standard, Roby and Hunter enter and drop into chairs.  Fa shortly.  They all look blank, stunned.
What happened?  Where's Sandy?
Dead.
Dead!
It's monstrous -- it grew, like some horrible tapeworm.  We were completely unprepared.
It's still in the ship?
We'd better seal off the lower maintenance level; at least trap it there. (throws a switch; circuitry lights up)
At least it can't get up here now.
Two down, four to go.
(angrily)
What's that supposed to mean?
Nothing.
Listen, it sure didn't like this flamethrower.
That's right -- we can't kill it on the ship, but we can at least keep it at bay -- and maybe drive it into the air lock.
Thing is, I'm about out of fuel.
There's some more combustible fuel down in the storage lockers next to the lounge. (rises)
I'll go get it.
No, I don't want us separated.
You just sealed it off; it can't get to that section.
Don't count on it.
We sure need this flamethrower.
All right... but do  not go below decks.
Right. (heads for the door)
And be right back. Faust exits.
I think it's time we took a hard look at those heiroglyphs. Roby begins to punch buttons; the photographs of the heir appear on some of the screens.
Can you make out any pattern in all that?
(baffled)
Well... yes... there's a pattern... but it's meaningless to me.
I know it looks like a senseless jumble, but if you look closely, there are recognizable forms.
Recognizable!  In that?
In symbolic form... very stylized...  but if you stare at it, you can see some of the different creatures we've been dealing with.
Well... I suppose that star-shaped thing could be the parasite that got on Broussard.  Is that what you mean?
And right next to it, that oval design with the markings -- it's a dead ringer for the spore casings.
